Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Centre

Hong Kong continues to be a globally competitive international financial centre. Throughout the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has taken various measures to promote the development and application of financial technology in the banking and payments sectors. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the transaction volume of the rapid payment system "FPS" surged significantly.

Hong Kong is strategically located at the forefront of Mainland China's financial market opening, able to seize the opportunities during the opening-up process. Leveraging world-class market infrastructure and programs such as "Shanghai-Hong Kong Connect," "Shenzhen-Hong Kong Connect," and the "Bond Connect," Hong Kong serves as a fundraising platform highly valued by Mainland Chinese enterprises and a gateway for international investors into the rapidly growing Mainland Chinese market. Within the year, good progress was made in promoting financial cooperation among Guangdong, Hong Kong, and Macau, especially in facilitating Hong Kong residents' access to financial and banking services within the Greater Bay Area.

Meanwhile, HKMA actively explores new opportunities to enhance Hong Kong’s financial platform, including asset and wealth management, corporate treasury centres, and sustainable finance competitiveness. HKMA also intensifies market promotion to overseas and Mainland stakeholders, showcasing Hong Kong’s financial services. Globally, the HKMA plays leadership roles in multiple regional and international committees, demonstrating Hong Kong’s expertise and responsibilities in relevant international engagements.

Overview

To consolidate Hong Kong’s position as an Asian fintech hub, HKMA continues to implement various measures to promote the development and application of technology in banking and payments. Major developments this year include:
- Promoting wider use of the FPS;
- Encouraging banks to implement open Application Programming Interfaces (APIs);
- Connecting the Trade Finance Platform "TradeLink" with the Mainland’s trade finance blockchain platform under the People's Bank of China (PBOC) to digitalize trade finance;
- Researching central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) for cross-border payments;
- Exploring the technical feasibility of "Trade Window" and researching new types of credit scoring models to assist SMEs in obtaining financing;
- Announcing a two-year plan to develop a more scalable and diversified regulatory technology ecosystem, further promoting RegTech application;
- Strengthening talent cultivation; and
- Advancing cross-border fintech cooperation.

The HKMA FinTech Facilitation Office (FFO) and various banking departments within the HKMA have played key roles in promoting these initiatives.

As major financial markets indices begin incorporating Mainland Chinese onshore securities or increasing their weights, capital inflows into RMB assets continue to accelerate. Hong Kong, with its unique advantage of connecting Mainland China capital markets through "Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect," "Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect," and the "Bond Connect," plays a crucial role in encouraging international investors to increase RMB asset allocations. In 2020, the average daily trading volume on the "Bond Connect" increased by 82%, reaching about RMB 19.3 billion. To improve the operation of the "Bond Connect," HKMA introduced new measures, including new special settlement cycles, extended trading hours, and new arrangements, providing investors with greater flexibility in currency exchange and foreign currency hedging through banks. Following the success of the Northbound Bond Connect, HKMA and PBOC formed a working group to explore the framework for the Southbound Bond Connect.

HKMA continues to strengthen financial arrangements between Hong Kong and Mainland cities within the Greater Bay Area. Mainland authorities announced a series of policies to support regional financial development. In June, the PBOC, HKMA, and the Monetary Authority of Macau jointly announced the implementation of cross-border "Wealth Management Connect." HKMA closely collaborates with Mainland and local authorities and industry players to develop detailed implementation rules. HKMA also maintains communication with Mainland authorities on other measures to expand policy space for Hong Kong banks and develop broader cross-border business models. Throughout the year, Hong Kong maintained its position as a global offshore RMB business hub, with the real-time RMB payment and settlement (RTGS) system achieving a record daily transaction amount of RMB 1.2 trillion.

HKMA actively explores new opportunities to enhance Hong Kong’s financial platform competitiveness. To promote the development of the local funds industry, HKMA works closely with the government and industry to create a more favourable tax and regulatory environment for fund domicile. HKMA also invests heavily in elevating Hong Kong’s status as a green and sustainable finance hub in the region. Meanwhile, HKMA enhances market promotion efforts, promoting Hong Kong’s financial services internationally and within Mainland China.

In the realm of central banking, HKMA assumes leadership roles in multiple regional and international committees, including chairing the Policy and Standards Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Markets Working Group under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks (EMEAP). HKMA also chairs the Non-bank Supervisory Expert Group and the Fintech Network co-chairs under the Financial Stability Board, leading efforts on regulatory issues related to transition to new benchmarks.

The security and efficient operation of Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure underpin Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre. In 2020, the four Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) systems for interbank transactions, the Central Maturity and Settlement System for debt instruments (CMU), and the Hong Kong Trade Data Repository all achieved 100% system availability, surpassing the target level of 99.95%. The CMU system continues to facilitate the settlement of "Bond Connect" Northbound transactions and hold Mainland securities on behalf of relevant CMU members through accounts at two Mainland depositories.

The usage of "FPS" continued to grow in 2020. By the end of the year, there were a total of 6.9 million registrations, with transaction volume doubling from 2019. The government’s acceptance of FPS payments and increased merchant adoption are key reasons for the remarkable growth in personal peer-to-peer transactions.

To ensure overall safety and efficiency of local retail payments, HKMA supervises six retail payment systems under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (PSSVO). HKMA also continues to regulate 18 stored value facility licensees.

2020 Review

Hong Kong’s Position as an Asian Fintech Hub

FPS

Since its launch in September 2018, 35 banks and 12 stored value facility operators have joined, including five banks and one stored value facility operator added in 2020. The use of FPS has steadily increased. As of December 31, there were 6.9 million registrations (see Figure 1). To facilitate citizens in receiving payments from institutions, FPS introduced a new feature in December that uses Hong Kong ID card numbers as account identifiers. Within less than a month, over 110,000 registrations were recorded. This feature is not for personal transfers but for institutions issuing payments to recipients with Hong Kong ID numbers (e.g., salary payments). Because each citizen’s ID number is unique, using it as an account identifier ensures accurate receipt of payments even without providing bank account numbers.

[Figure 1: Number of FPS account registrations]

The COVID-19 pandemic and social distancing measures provided a new impetus for electronic payment services. During the year, FPS transaction volume grew rapidly (see Figure 2). As of December 2020, the average daily transactions reached 505,000 real-time transactions involving HKD 5.2 billion and RMB 95 million, three times the 168,000 transactions in December 2019 and ten times the first month’s volume when FPS was launched in October 2018. The growth was also supported by expanding application scope—from primarily P2P payments to bill payments (including government bills), retail, and commercial transactions.

[Figure 2: Average daily transaction volume of instant HKD payments]

HKMA has cooperated with multiple government departments and banks to extend FPS’s application from P2P payments to bill payments and other merchant payments. The government began accepting bill payments via FPS in November 2019 to promote its use and make life more convenient for citizens. Citizens can scan QR codes printed on bills via mobile banking or e-wallets supporting FPS to pay taxes, rates, rents, water bills, and general government bills easily. By December 2020, the number of government bills paid via FPS reached 1.8 million transactions, involving HKD 2.2 billion. Following the successful rollout of government bill payment services, four additional government departments started accepting FPS payments at designated counters and self-service machines from December 21, 2020. The government is also exploring online FPS payment arrangements.

Another positive trend is the increasing adoption of FPS by merchants of all sizes to enhance business operations. By December 2020, the number of merchant transactions reached an average of 100,000 per day, a 38-fold increase from December 2019, with widespread use for bill payments, in-app direct debits, and online shopping. The rising popularity of e-wallets has further driven the significant increase in transactions involving account top-ups via FPS. In December 2020, the average daily value of top-up transactions was seven times that of December 2019.

To raise public awareness about FPS, HKMA produces educational and promotional materials, including TV ads and a series of "smart tips" on social media platforms. HKMA held a WhatsApp sticker design contest for secondary school students to increase their awareness of electronic payments. Additionally, HKMA promoted FPS usage among charitable organizations and street market operators. Many participating banks and stored value facility operators launched campaigns with incentives to encourage registration and use of FPS for transfers and bill payments. In early 2021, HKMA collaborated with banks and operators to promote digitalized "lai see" payments during the Lunar New Year, simultaneously launching promotional campaigns and offering incentives to encourage customers to give lai see electronically—supporting environmental protection and pandemic response.

# 儲備管理

2020年是峰迴路轉的一年，新冠病毒疫情為全球經濟帶來前所未有的挑戰。資產市場於第1 季經歷了大幅調整和震盪後，在主要央行推出超寬鬆的貨幣政策及各地政府實施大規模的財政紓困措施帶動下，得以迅速反彈。由於主要央行大幅下調基準利率並重啟量化寬鬆措施，令國債收益率顯著下跌、債券價格上升。在此投資環境下，外匯基金在2020 年錄得2,358 億港元的投資收入，回報率為5.3%。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：
(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產配置於較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一，以及未來基金存款與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，一直持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但未來基金屬主要個別例子。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為40：60。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，會以投資基準方式反映，亦即外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，透過戰略性的資產配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內管理倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局的外匯基金投資辦公室專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分投資組合包括不同的環球定息市場投資，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，獲取可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專門的投資知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，風險管理的重要性不言而喻。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂下嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並設立嚴謹的風險監察及合規制度。金管局為投資相關活動設有三重防線以確保有效的風險管理及監察。金管局亦定期監察主要投資風險類別（包括信用、市場、流動性及業務操作風險），並已加強風險管理程序以配合外匯基金的多元化投資。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資，將環境、社會及管治(ESG)因素併入外匯基金的公開市場及私募市場的投資管理過程。

金管局訂有一套原則，以評估外匯基金投資項目的ESG風險與機會。就外聘投資經理所管理的資產組合而言，金管局透過獲委任的投資經理執行負責任投資。在甄選、委任及監察外聘投資經理的過程中，金管局會評估其落實ESG的不同範疇，包括ESG管治方面的組織架構、ESG標準及政策、將ESG因素併入投資程序中的情況，以及管理督導的業務活動，即代理投票和與投資組合公司的溝通（例如與投資組合公司管理層商討ESG的事宜）。為彰顯對負責任投資的重視，金管局透過外聘投資經理在管理督導方面扮演的角色，推動更完善的ESG做法。負責管理金管局的香港股票組合及中國內地股票主動投資管理組合的外聘投資經理，須承諾遵守證券及期貨事務監察委員會頒布的《負責任的擁有權原則》，若未能遵守則須作出解釋。至於負責管理已發展市場股票組合的外聘投資經理則需恪守國際公認的ESG標準。此外，金管局又展開聘任後監察計劃，以審視外聘投資經理的代理投票及與投資組合公司溝通的落實概況。

由金管局內部人員負責管理的定息投資組合，亦將ESG因素融入債券投資的信用風險分析中。藉著擴大ESG數據來源以及在量化評估中提高ESG因素的權重，加強相關的分析。

至於在公開市場的ESG投資，金管局自2015年起投資於綠色、社會責任及可持續債券（ESG債券），是這個市場的早期投資者之一。此外，金管局亦參與國際金融公司的「聯合貸款組合管理計劃」，而其投資對象聚焦於新興市場的可持續發展項目。在2020年，適逢市場供應增加，金管局增加ESG債券的投資。展望未來，金管局將繼續透過直接投資或持有ESG債券基金等方式，壯大其ESG債券組合。此外，金管局將透過採納ESG股票指數作為被動投資組合的投資基準，推動外聘投資經理建立以ESG為主題的股票投資方針。金管局在未來幾年將會繼續留意以ESG為主題的投資機會，例如主動式的ESG投資組合及低碳為題的投資工具。

私募市場投資方面，金管局在盡職審查過程中檢視專責合夥人的ESG政策及具體措施。金管局的長期增長組合積極投資於具備可持續特點的項目，包括可再生能源基建，而在房地產投資組合亦有吸納具有綠色及可持續特點的倉庫及其他建築物。金管局將在未來繼續物色具備可持續特點的項目，並在房地產投資方面將綠色認證列入為重要考慮因素。金管局與專責合夥人舉行年度ESG工作坊，就良好的ESG作業手法交流意見及經驗。在11月舉行的ESG工作坊上，一眾專責合夥人就新冠病毒疫情對其投資組合公司及ESG投資發展所造成的影響交換意見。為提高私募市場投資的ESG透明度，金管局已要求專責合夥人提供有關其投資項目的ESG資訊，例如氣候變化風險等，以便監察。

金管局往後仍會密切觀察ESG標準的發展，評估如何將有關標準進一步融入投資程序，當中包括與理念相近的投資者及國際組織互動合作。金管局作為聯合國支持的《負責任投資原則》的簽署人之一，肩負作為全球倡導者的責任，日後將會參與制定ESG最佳作業手法，並推動其他投資者採納負責任的投資方法。金管局亦是非牟利機構 FCLTGlobal 的成員，該機構旨在透過舉辦工作坊及研究，鼓勵以長遠目標為本的業務及投資決策。金管局亦有參與「氣候相關財務資訊披露工作小組」，並為「央行與監管機構綠色金融網絡」的成員。此外，金管局籌辦講座及積極參與投資業界舉辦的活動，分享及推廣有關ESG投資的理念。

有關金管局的負責任投資政策架構，詳見「機構社會責任」一章。

# 2020年的金融市場

# Reserve Management

2020 was a year of significant turnaround. The COVID-19 pandemic brought unprecedented challenges to the global economy. After experiencing substantial adjustments and volatility in the asset markets in the first quarter, a rapid rebound was achieved thanks to ultra-loose monetary policies introduced by major central banks and large-scale fiscal relief measures implemented by governments around the world. Due to significant cuts in benchmark interest rates and the resumption of quantitative easing by major central banks, government bond yields fell sharply and bond prices rose. In this investment environment, the Foreign Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$235.8 billion in 2020, with a return of 5.3%.

# Foreign Exchange Fund

Under the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary purpose of the Exchange Fund is to directly or indirectly influence the exchange rate of the HK dollar, as well as to maintain the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems, thereby safeguarding Hong Kong's status as an international financial centre. The Monetary Authority, under delegated authority from the Financial Secretary and according to the terms of such delegation, is responsible to the Financial Secretary for the use and investment management of the Exchange Fund.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee (EFAC) has established the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:
(a) To safeguard the capital;
(b) To ensure that the overall monetary base is always fully supported by liquidity-high US dollar assets;
(c) To ensure sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(d) To strive for investment returns compatible with the above (a) to (c) to safeguard the fund’s long-term purchasing power.

These objectives fully reflect the statutory purpose of the Exchange Fund and are incorporated into its portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

Broadly, the Exchange Fund is divided into two main portfolios: the support portfolio and the investment portfolio. The support portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets, which, according to the Monetary Authority’s system, provide full support to the monetary base. The investment portfolio mainly invests in bond and equity markets of member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), aimed at preserving asset value and long-term purchasing power.

To better manage risks and enhance medium- to long-term returns, the Monetary Authority adopts a prudent and gradual approach, diversifying the assets of the Exchange Fund to include emerging markets and Mainland China bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging markets and Mainland China bonds and equities are held within the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held within the long-term growth portfolio. The market value cap for the long-term growth portfolio is one-third of the cumulative surplus of the Exchange Fund, as well as the total of future fund deposits and the portion linked to long-term growth portfolios of subsidiaries of the Exchange Fund.

The strategic asset portfolio was established in 2007 and has maintained holdings of shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased for strategic purposes. Due to the unique nature of this portfolio, its investment performance is not included in the overall evaluation of the Exchange Fund’s performance.

# Deposits in the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund occasionally receives deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations. The interest rate typically tracks the performance of the investment portfolio, but the future fund’s deposits are the principal cases. The interest rate on future fund deposits is linked to the performance of the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual rate depending on the portfolio proportions. The approximate ratio of future fund deposits in the investment portfolio to those in the long-term growth portfolio is about 40:60.

# Investment Procedures

The investment procedures of the Exchange Fund are based on strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. The strategic asset allocation, reflected through investment benchmarks, represents the long-term asset mix designed to meet the investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic targets as guidance and adopts tactical adjustments to strive for returns exceeding benchmarks. As a result, actual allocations often deviate from benchmarks, with the difference termed “strategic deviation.” The Financial Secretary, after consulting EFAC, sets investment benchmarks and permissible tracking error limits, while the Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the strategic asset allocation and establish acceptable ranges for strategic deviations. Portfolio managers may manage holdings within these limits to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investment

The Exchange Fund Investment Office (EFIO) of the Monetary Authority is responsible for investment and related risk management functions. Staff in EFIO manage approximately 72% of the assets directly, including the entire support portfolio and part of the investment portfolio. These investments include various global fixed income markets and macro-risk management strategies using derivatives.

# External Investment Managers

In addition to internal staff managing assets, the Monetary Authority employs external investment managers responsible for approximately 28% of the assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of appointing external managers is to leverage market-leading professional expertise, gaining sustainable returns, and benefitting from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as market insights and specialized knowledge.

Expenses related to external managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other applicable taxes, which vary annually depending on market conditions.

# Risk Management and Oversight

As the investment environment becomes increasingly complex, effective risk management is of utmost importance. The Monetary Authority has established strict controls and investment guidelines for both internal and external managers, along with rigorous risk monitoring and compliance systems. To ensure effective risk management and oversight, the Authority employs a three-tiered defense system. It also regularly monitors key categories of investment risks—including credit, market, liquidity, and operational risks—and has strengthened risk management procedures to support the diversification of the Exchange Fund’s investments.

# Responsible Investment

The Monetary Authority supports responsible investment, integrating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into the management processes of both public market and private market investments of the Exchange Fund.

The Authority has a set of principles to evaluate ESG risks and opportunities of investment projects. For assets managed by external managers, the Authority executes responsible investment through delegated managers. During the process of selecting, appointing, and monitoring external managers, the Authority assesses their implementation of ESG practices, including organizational structure, standards and policies, integration of ESG factors into investment procedures, and oversight activities such as proxy voting and engagement with portfolio companies. To underscore the importance of responsible investment, the Authority promotes better ESG practices by leveraging the role of external managers in stewardship activities. External managers responsible for actively managing the Hong Kong stock portfolio and Mainland China stock active portfolios must commit to adhering to the Securities and Futures Commission’s Principles for Responsible Ownership; failure to comply requires explanation. Managers overseeing developed market equity portfolios are required to follow internationally recognized ESG standards. Additionally, the Authority has initiated post-appointment monitoring programs to review how external managers implement proxy voting and engagement.

For fixed income portfolios managed internally by the Authority, ESG factors are incorporated into credit risk analyses. By expanding ESG data sources and increasing the weight of ESG factors in quantitative assessments, the Authority enhances related analysis.

In terms of public market ESG investments, the Authority has been investing in green, social responsibility, and sustainable bonds (ESG bonds) since 2015, being among the early investors in this market. The Authority also participates in the International Financial Corporation’s (IFC) “Sustainable Lending Portfolio Management Program,” focusing on projects supporting sustainable development in emerging markets. In 2020, amid increased market supply, the Authority increased investments in ESG bonds. Looking ahead, the Authority will continue expanding its ESG bond portfolio through direct investments and holdings of ESG bond funds. Additionally, it plans to promote an ESG-themed stock investment approach for external managers by adopting ESG stock indices as benchmarks for passive portfolios. The Authority will also continue to monitor opportunities in ESG-focused investments, such as active ESG portfolios and low-carbon investment tools.

In private markets, the Authority reviews ESG policies and specific measures of dedicated partnerships during due diligence. The long-term growth portfolio actively invests in sustainable projects, including renewable energy infrastructure, and its real estate investments include green-certified warehouses and other buildings. The Authority plans to continue identifying projects with sustainable features and will consider green certification as a key criterion in real estate investments. The Authority holds annual ESG workshops with dedicated partners to exchange insights and best practices. During the November workshop, participants discussed the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their portfolio companies and ESG development. To increase transparency of ESG investments in private markets, the Authority has requested partners to provide ESG information (such as climate risk data).

The Authority will continue to closely observe the development of ESG standards, considering how to further incorporate these standards into investment processes, including engaging with like-minded investors and international organizations. As a signatory of the UN-supported Principles for Responsible Investment, the Authority commits to advocating best practices and promoting responsible investing among other investors. It is also a member of the non-profit organization FCLTGlobal, which encourages long-term value-based decision-making through workshops and research. The Authority participates in the Climate-related Financial Disclosures Working Group and is a member of the Central Bank and Supervisors’ Green Finance Network. Furthermore, the Authority organises seminars and actively participates in industry events to promote and share ESG investment principles.

For details of the Monetary Authority’s responsible investment policy framework, please refer to the chapter on “Corporate Social Responsibility.”

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

# Financial Markets in 2020

Supported by accommodative monetary and fiscal policies introduced in response to the significant challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic to the global economy, the global financial markets reached record highs at the end of the year. After experiencing major adjustments and volatility in the first quarter, global stock markets rebounded rapidly, with major markets attaining double-digit growth. The US S&P 500 index rose by 16%, making it one of the best-performing among the seven major industrialized countries’ stock indices in 2020.

In the bond markets, yields of bonds from major developed countries continued to come under pressure after a marked decline in the first quarter. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury note fell approximately 100 basis points from 1.9% at the start of the year to 0.9% at year-end. The sharp rise in government bond prices resulted in notable valuation gains in 2020.

In the money markets, declining US interest rates narrowed the interest rate differentials, weakening the US dollar against major currencies. This trend was particularly evident in the second half of 2020, with the euro and renminbi appreciating by about 9.0% and 6.5% respectively against the US dollar.

金管局透過傳統及社交媒體、網站、資訊中心及其他渠道與社會及市場保持有效溝通，增進公眾對金管局政策及運作的了解。對內方面，金管局亦致力加強機構管治，包括支持員工提升專業能力、嚴格控制財政、加強資訊科技保安，以及鼓勵創新文化，以應對推行新項目及日益繁重的工作所帶來的挑戰。

# 與公眾保持聯繫

# 傳媒關係與社交媒體

金管局與傳媒保持緊密聯繫，以提高金管局的透明度，並增進公眾對其政策及運作的了解。金管局在2020年共舉辦93次實體及線上活動，包括8次新聞發布會、5次即場訪問及80次其他公開活動，又安排了14次媒體訪談，並發布552份雙語新聞稿，每日亦處理大量傳媒查詢。

為增進社會對金管局主要職能的認識，金管局為本地和海外媒體以及言論具影響力的人士舉辦傳媒簡報會及工作坊，涵蓋聯繫匯率制度、金融科技、綠色金融及宏觀審慎監管措施等主題。

金管局金融科技總監周文正先生（左）接受彭博訪問。

金管局透過社交媒體增進各界對其工作的了解，以及加強與公眾溝通，目前共營運5個社交媒體專頁，包括 Facebook、Instagram、LinkedIn、Twitter及YouTube。截至2020年12月底，逾66,500名用戶關注金管局的社交媒體專頁。針對新冠病毒疫情，金管局善用社交媒體繼續與公眾聯繫，以及有效澄清與金融及銀行體系穩定相關的不實謠言。

公眾查詢服務是增進市民對金管局主要職能及運作認識的有效渠道，在2020年共處理9,514宗查詢，其中約一半涉及銀行業政策及規例、銀行消費者事宜、紙幣與硬幣、金融基建及債券市場發展，特別是硬幣收集計劃、銀行產品及服務、銀行業相關指引及通告、零售債券發行計劃，以及貨幣與經濟數據。

# 刊物

除金管局《年報》外，年內金管局出版兩期《貨幣與金融穩定情況半年度報告》及4期《季報》，並定期更新《金融數據月報》資料，提供有關香港貨幣、銀行業及經濟事務的最新及專題資料與分析。此外，金管局共發表18篇《匯思》文章，介紹金管局的重要措施及政策，並討論公眾關注的事項。

# 金管局網站

金管局的官方網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)提供4萬多頁英文及繁簡字體中文版資料，方便公眾查閱金管局的最新資訊。網站亦載有根據《銀行業條例》第20條備存的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」，以及根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》備存的「儲值支付工具持牌人紀錄冊」。

金管局自2018年起透過開放應用程式介面（開放API），分階段發放在其網站所載的金融數據及重要資訊。截至2020年底，金管局如期在網站推出合共144組開放API。

金管局積極支持開放API的發展及應用。

# 金管局資訊中心

金管局資訊中心設於國際金融中心2期55樓，向公眾介紹金管局工作及提高公眾對貨幣與銀行業事宜的了解。資訊中心分為展覽館及圖書館兩部分。展覽館以互動方式介紹金管局的工作，以及香港貨幣與銀行業的發展；另備資料與展品，供研究香港貨幣、銀行業與金融事務。毗鄰展覽館的圖書館收藏超過26,000本書籍、期刊及其他刊物，以供研究香港貨幣、銀行業、金融和中央銀行事務等課題。圖書館亦備存《銀行業條例》第20條規定的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」。

金管局資訊中心憑藉其精心設計及獨樹一格的氛圍，從全球各地千多名參賽者中脫穎而出，成為「2020年MUSE DESIGN AWARDS」室內設計組別白金獎的得獎者之一。

資訊中心善用在2020年因應新冠病毒疫情暫停開放的時機，優化了「政策」展區的設施。該展區闡述金管局的工作，並介紹相關的金融概念。有關優化措施是因應訪客意見而作出，使互動設施更易使用、更富趣味及更耐用，令參觀過程更有樂趣。

資訊中心的開放及服務時間因疫情持續而受到影響。為保障公眾安全及維持高水平的衛生環境，年內資訊中心實施特別開放安排及防疫措施，並加強清潔及消毒，設施及展品更定期以長效殺菌塗層消毒。

# 公眾及消費者教育

為與社區保持聯繫及增進市民對金管局工作的認識，金管局在2020年舉辦了一場網上公眾教育講座，吸引1,600多名來自61間中學的師生參加。講座內容涵蓋金管局工作簡介、聯繫匯率制度、香港鈔票、保障個人數碼鎖匙及存款保障計劃。教育講座自1998年推出以來，首次以網上形式舉行，至今已有超過61,000名師生參與。

超過1,600名來自61間中學的師生參加金管局網上公眾教育講座。

金管局教育公眾做個精明及負責任的金融服務消費者，並就此與公眾保持聯繫。相關教育工作的其中一個重點繼續是「保護個人數碼鎖匙」，年內金管局製作了一系列短片，呼籲市民不論何時何地都要妥善保管財務帳戶及個人資料。鑑於新冠病毒疫情下網上騙案有所增加，金管局提醒市民在網上購物或使用個人認證資料時要提高警覺，慎防詐騙圈套。

為提高年青人加入金管局工作的興趣，金管局於2020年推出公眾教育網劇《STEPS》，並在社交媒體發布一系列相關貼文，介紹金管局在貨幣、聯繫匯率制度、金融科技、普及金融、銀行監管與國際合作等範疇的工作。

公眾教育網劇《STEPS》以輕鬆的手法，透過一個新入職年青人的成長故事，介紹金管局的主要職能。

金管局在數碼平台及戶外媒體廣泛宣傳保護個人數碼鎖匙的訊息。

金管局支持投資者及理財教育委員會提升香港市民的金融理財知識及能力，並會研究與持份者進一步合作，提高社區參與的成效。

# 金管局員工

金管局是政府架構的一部分，但按非公務員條款聘請員工，吸引具適當經驗及專門知識的人才。金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作團隊，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作要求的轉變。

金管局在2020年的人手編制為1,005人。年內，金管局致力透過靈活調配現有資源、提升效率及精簡工作程序，以配合新項目的需要及日益繁重的工作。金管局在2021年的人手編制將維持1,005人，並會重新調配現有資源，應付下述新開展及有所擴展的工作：

# 銀行及金融體系穩定
- 支援「理財通」的政策發展工作，以及其他粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）與私人財富管理措施，以及持續監管「理財通」業務
- 處理《保險業條例》及新的場外衍生工具制度下的發牌工作，以及有關虛擬銀行的操守監管工作
- 實施有關氣候風險的新監管規定，以及加強對銀行的審慎監管

# 儲備管理
- 加強投資、風險管理及其他必要支援，以配合外匯基金持續擴展及多元化的投資工作

# 香港的國際金融中心地位
- 為加強參與金融穩定理事會及其他國際工作小組提供支援
- 管理新近建議的附帶權益稅務寬減制度，以及核實可合資格獲稅務寬減的基金

# 薪酬福利政策及薪酬檢討機制

財政司司長透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的意見，並參考市場薪酬水平及做法，決定金管局員工的薪酬及服務條件。薪酬組合包括現金薪酬及公積金，另設一些基本福利。現金薪酬包括每月固定薪酬（即基本薪酬）及根據員工工作表現每年一次過發放的浮動薪酬。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以作獎勵及保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬及浮動薪酬的款項；而適用於負責投資的員工的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁及以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Institutional Functions

The HKMA maintains effective communication with society and the market through traditional and social media, the website, information centers, and other channels, enhancing public understanding of its policies and operations. Internally, the HKMA is also committed to strengthening corporate governance, including supporting staff in enhancing professional capabilities, strictly controlling finances, strengthening information technology security, and encouraging an innovative culture to meet the challenges posed by implementing new initiatives and increasingly heavy workloads.

# Staying in Touch with the Public

# Media Relations and Social Media

The HKMA maintains close ties with the media to increase transparency and enhance the public’s understanding of its policies and operations. In 2020, it organized a total of 93 on-site and online events, including 8 press conferences, 5 on-location interviews, and 80 other public activities; additionally, 14 media interviews were arranged, and 552 bilingual press releases were issued. The HKMA also handled a large volume of media inquiries daily.

To increase social awareness of the HKMA’s main functions, the HKMA holds media briefings and workshops for local and overseas media and influential opinion leaders, covering topics such as the Linked Exchange Rate system, financial technology, green finance, and macroprudential measures.

HKMA Chief Executive Mr. Norman Chan hosted an online panel discussion at the “Hong Kong Fintech Week 2020.”

Deputy Chief Executive Mr. John Tsang (center) hosted a media briefing introducing the HKMA’s two-year plan to promote compliance technology applications.

HKMA Financial Technology Director Mr. Winston Chow (left) gave an interview to Bloomberg.

The HKMA enhances understanding of its work and strengthens communication with the public through social media. Currently, it operates five social media pages, including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Twitter, and YouTube. As of the end of December 2020, over 66,500 users followed the HKMA’s social media pages. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the HKMA effectively used social media to maintain contact with the public and clarify false rumors related to financial stability and the banking system.

# Public Inquiries

Public inquiry services serve as an effective channel for increasing citizens’ awareness of the HKMA’s core functions and operations. In 2020, a total of 9,514 inquiries were handled, with about half relating to banking policies and regulations, banking consumer issues, banknotes and coins, financial infrastructure, and bond market development—especially about the coins collection scheme, banking products and services, relevant guidelines and notices, retail bond issuance plans, and monetary and economic data.

Figure 1 shows the total number of public inquiries received annually since 2017, while Figure 2 depicts the proportion of different categories of inquiries received in 2020.

Figure 2: Distribution of Inquiries in 2020 by Category

# Publications

In addition to the HKMA Annual Report, during the year, the HKMA published two semi-annual reports on monetary and financial stability, four quarterly reports, and regularly updated data in the Financial Data Monthly to provide the latest and topical information and analysis on Hong Kong’s monetary, banking, and economic affairs. Furthermore, the HKMA issued 18 articles in the “BIS Review,” introducing important measures and policies, and discussing issues of public concern.

The HKMA’s 2019 Annual Report received the Silver Award in the “Non-Profit and Charitable Organizations” category at the Association of International Certified Professional Accountants’ 2020 Best Annual Reports Awards.

# HKMA Website

The official website (www.hkma.gov.hk) offers over 40,000 pages of information in English and Chinese (Traditional and Simplified), facilitating public access to the latest HKMA news. The website also contains records of “Recognized institutions and local representative offices” and the “Record of recognized securities firms,” pursuant to Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as records of “Recognized stored value facility licensees,” under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facility Ordinance.

Since 2018, the HKMA has been offering financial data and key information via open Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) in phases on its website. By the end of 2020, a total of 144 API groups had been launched as scheduled.

The HKMA actively supports the development and application of open APIs.

# HKMA Information Centre

Located on the 55th floor of Two International Finance Centre, the HKMA Information Centre introduces the HKMA’s work and enhances the public’s understanding of monetary and banking affairs. It comprises an exhibition hall and a library. The exhibition hall presents the HKMA’s work in an interactive manner and showcases the development of Hong Kong’s monetary and banking sectors; it also provides materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong’s monetary, banking, financial, and central banking topics. The adjacent library holds over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications for research purposes.

Thanks to its thoughtfully designed and distinctive environment, the HKMA Information Centre was awarded a Platinum Prize in the interior design category at the “2020 Muse Design Awards,” among over a thousand participants worldwide.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the centre optimized the “Policy” exhibition area during its temporary closure, to better explain the HKMA’s work and financial concepts. Improvements were driven by visitor feedback, making the interactive facilities easier to use, more engaging, and more durable, thereby enhancing visitor experience.

The interactive facilities in the “Policy” area have been updated accordingly.

The exhibition hall provides an overview of the HKMA’s work and the development of Hong Kong’s monetary and banking sectors.

To ensure the centre remains accessible and inclusive to visitors of all races, a procedure was developed to provide interpretation services for visitors in need and for callers to the centre hotline.

The centre’s opening hours and services have been affected by ongoing pandemic restrictions. To protect public health and maintain high hygiene standards, the centre implemented special opening arrangements, reinforced cleaning and disinfection, and used long-lasting sterilization coatings on facilities and exhibits.

# Public and Consumer Education

To maintain contact with the community and increase awareness of the HKMA’s work, in 2020, the HKMA held an online public education seminar, which attracted over 1,600 teachers and students from 61 secondary schools. The seminar covered an introduction to the HKMA’s work, the Linked Exchange Rate system, Hong Kong banknotes, safeguarding digital keys, and the Deposit Guarantee Scheme. First held online since its inception in 1998, this event has involved over 61,000 teachers and students to date.

Over 1,600 teachers and students from 61 secondary schools participated in the HKMA’s online public education seminar.

The HKMA educates the public to become smart and responsible consumers of financial services, maintaining ongoing communication. One key focus is on “protecting digital keys,” with the HKMA producing a series of short videos urging citizens to safeguard their financial accounts and personal data at all times. In response to rising online scams during the pandemic, the HKMA reminds the public to be vigilant when shopping online and using personal authentication data, to prevent scams.

To increase young people's interest in working at the HKMA, the HKMA launched the “STEPS” online drama series in 2020, and posted related content on social media to introduce the HKMA’s key roles in areas including currency, the Linked Exchange Rate system, financial technology, financial literacy promotion, banking supervision, and international cooperation.

The public education web series “STEPS” uses a light-hearted approach, narrating the growth story of a young newcomer to introduce the HKMA’s main functions.

The HKMA promotes the message of protecting personal digital keys through digital platforms and outdoor media.

Additionally, the HKMA collaborates with various community activities and stakeholders, including the online parent-child financial literacy event “Little Financial Governor,” which uses animated videos, online games, DIY toys, downloadable worksheets, and coloring competitions to teach kindergarten and primary students basic concepts of money and financial literacy, as well as fundamental knowledge of banking and payment services.

An animated video featuring the Dollar Pig mascot and the Kam family conveys messages on five key themes.

Demonstration of toy-making using environmentally friendly materials.

Other youth educational activities include online financial literacy Q&A competitions, webinars aimed at secondary school students and teachers, a comic book co-produced with a professional organization targeting primary school children and parents, and online lectures for university students.

The HKMA supports the Investor and Financial Education Council in enhancing financial literacy among Hong Kong citizens and will explore further collaboration with stakeholders to improve community engagement.

# HKMA Employees

The HKMA is part of the government framework but hires staff under a non-civil servant terms, attracting talent with appropriate experience and expertise. The HKMA employs, trains, and maintains a professional and high-caliber team to fulfill policy objectives and flexibly respond to changing work demands.

As of 2020, the HKMA had an authorized staffing of 1,005 personnel. During the year, the HKMA focused on efficient resource allocation, improving efficiency, and streamlining procedures to support new initiatives and cope with the increasing workload. The staffing level remains at 1,005 in 2021, with existing resources being reallocated to handle new and expanded responsibilities including:

# Stability of Banking and Financial Systems
- Supporting policy development for “Fintech Supervisory Sandbox” and other Mainland, Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (GBA) private wealth management measures, as well as ongoing regulation of “fintech” activities
- Handling licensing under the Insurance Ordinance and the new OTC derivatives regime, including conduct regulatory oversight of virtual banks
- Implementing new supervisory rules related to climate risk and strengthening prudential regulation of banks

# Reserves Management
- Enhancing investment, risk management, and other support functions to align with the continued expansion and diversification of the Exchange Fund’s investments

# Hong Kong’s Position as an International Financial Centre
- Supporting participation in the Financial Stability Board and other international task forces
- Managing proposed new marginal tax relief schemes and verifying eligibility of funds for tax relief

Table 1 presents the HKMA’s organizational structure and actual staff numbers by department.

Table 1: Staffing Structure and Actual Staff as of January 1, 2021

# Compensation and Benefits Policies and Review Mechanisms

The Financial Secretary, through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, consults the HKMA’s Governing Committee and considers market compensation levels and practices when determining staff salaries and terms of service. The remuneration package includes cash salary and MPF contributions, along with some basic benefits. Cash salary consists of a fixed monthly salary (basic pay) and an annual lump-sum performance-based bonus.

When reviewing HKMA staff remuneration annually, the Financial Secretary consults the Governing Committee via the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, considers the previous year’s performance assessments, results of compensation surveys by independent HR consulting firms in the financial industry, and other relevant factors. Outstanding performers may receive special adjustments to reward and maintain their competitive salary levels.

Based on individual work performance, the HKMA allocates funds approved for annual fixed and variable pay adjustments. For staff responsible for investments, the variable pay system aims to better link investment performance with remuneration. The fixed salary adjustments and bonus payments for senior management above Assistant General Managers are approved by the Financial Secretary after review and with reference to the Governing Committee’s advice, with relevant staff excusing themselves from discussions concerning their own salaries. Salary adjustments and bonus payments for staff at managerial and below levels are decided by the HKMA Chief Executive based on the approved funds as authorized by the Financial Secretary.

# 機構社會責任

金管局致力履行機構社會責任，以成為負責任及可持續發展的機構為目標。金管局在不同領域履行此承諾，包括推動可持續發展及具環保意識的市場、關懷廣大社會、保護環境及締造友善的工作環境。

為應對新冠病毒疫情，金管局推出多項措施，支援有需要的個人及企業，從而協助香港經濟渡過難關。

# 市場環境

# 綠色及可持續金融

氣候變化是影響人類福祉及全球經濟可持續性的主要風險之一，作為社會重要環節之一的金融體系，亦難免會受到影響；而銀行作為金融體系的一部分，應更積極管理氣候風險。有見及此，金管局致力探究應對這項挑戰的方法，並正落實多項於2019年5月宣布推出的措施，促進綠色金融在香港的發展。有關措施包括分三階段推動綠色及可持續銀行業的發展：

# 第一階段

與業界建立一個共同框架，評估銀行目前的「綠色基準」，以及與國際組織合作，為本港銀行提供技術支援；

# 第二階段

就綠色及可持續銀行業的監管期望及要求諮詢業界及其他持份者；以及

# 第三階段

集中落實、審視及評估銀行在這方面的進度。

在國際層面，金管局參與多個國際組織，包括央行與監管機構綠色金融網絡、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會轄下的氣候相關財務風險高級別工作組、東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議轄下銀行監管工作小組之下的可持續金融關注組及國際可持續金融平台。透過參與這些國際組織，金管局有機會為中央銀行界及監管機構在應對氣候變化的工作上作出貢獻，並能在制定本地架構時借鑑其他地區的經驗與觀點。

金管局亦參與央行與監管機構綠色金融網絡下的多個工作組，包括微觀審慎監管工作組、宏觀金融工作組及促進綠色金融工作組。此外，金管局亦加入了兩個新設的工作組：研究工作組及彌補數據缺口工作組。研究工作組負責相關研究工作，而彌補數據缺口工作組旨在制定監管當局及金融機構評估氣候相關風險與機遇所需、但目前卻並未掌握的數據項目詳盡清單。有關金管局年內在推動綠色及可持續銀行業發展方面的工作，詳見「銀行體系穩定」一章。

金管局在11月與國際金融公司聯合推出綠色商業銀行聯盟，協助各新興市場的銀行制定應對氣候變化的方案。作為聯盟的創始成員及首個區域執行理事，金管局i)在全球金融市場推動發展綠色商業銀行；ii)為商業銀行提供互相學習平台，獲取所需知識、工具及商業資訊，以制定其本身的綠色金融路線圖，並轉型為具公信力的綠色銀行；iii)促進溝通，並探討前沿議題推動全球綠色議程；以及iv)協助聯盟的成員合作，以及把握國際金融公司所識別在未來10年估計高達23萬億美元的新興市場綠色及氣候相關投資機會。

本地方面，金管局與其他金融監管機構合作，協調金融業針對氣候和環境風險的措施應對。除了協助政府落實政府綠色債券計劃的相關工作外，金管局亦與證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）共同發起成立了綠色和可持續金融跨機構督導小組（督導小組），處理跨行業的監管及市場發展事宜。有關金管局年內在發展香港成為綠色及可持續金融樞紐方面的工作，詳見「香港的國際金融中心地位」一章。

# 綠色和可持續金融跨機構督導小組

督導小組旨在協調金融業針對氣候及環境風險的措施應對、加快香港綠色及可持續金融的發展，以及支持政府的氣候策略。督導小組由金管局與證監會於5月共同發起成立，其他成員包括環境局、財經事務及庫務局、香港交易及結算所有限公司、保險業監管局及強制性公積金計劃管理局。

自成立以來，督導小組設立了兩個技術工作專責團隊，分別負責研究及處理跨部門的監管事宜，以及協調跨機構的市場發展工作。

督導小組在12月發布綠色及可持續金融策略，提出從六方面鞏固香港金融生態系統，長遠共建更綠色及更可持續的未來。督導小組亦宣布5個短期行動綱領，處理發展過程中一些最迫切的問題。

金管局舉辦督導小組成立大會，金管局總裁余偉文先生（右三）為該小組的聯席主席。

督導小組發布香港的綠色和可持續金融策略計劃及5個主要行動綱領。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資，即將環境、社會及管治(ESG)因素融入投資活動中。金管局作為規模龐大的資產擁有人，日益關注負責任投資，將對其基金經理如何進行投資活動產生影響。

# 金管局的信念

金管局相信透過適度強調負責任投資及考慮各項投資的可持續長期表現，將更有效達致外匯基金的投資目標，並且減低投資活動所涉及的ESG相關風險。

# 金管局的原則

按金管局採取的指導性原則，當ESG投資與其他投資項目的經風險調整長期收益相若時，一般會優先考慮ESG投資。作為負責任的長期投資者，金管局在投資管理過程中，會因應情況採納以下的負責任投資原則：

# 融入

金管局相信ESG因素會對投資項目的長期價值帶來重大影響，因此將ESG因素融入投資分析程序，以辨察風險及物色良機。金管局將ESG因素併入公開市場及私募市場的投資管理過程中。

# 主動行使資產擁有權

金管局就所持有的上市公司股票適當地行使股東權利，以維護投資的長期價值。金管局相信，顧及ESG因素的負責任企業行為，將有助創造長綫的股東利益。金管局期望外聘投資經理透過行使表決權及與獲投資公司溝通時，主動行使資產擁有權，藉以協助金管局履行對投資項目的擁有權責任。

# 合作

金管局致力與理念相近的投資者及監管機構合作，推動良好的長期投資管理手法，又出席公開活動並發表演講，分享更完善的ESG作業手法及鼓勵投資界採納負責任投資理念。

有關金管局年內在負責任投資方面的工作，詳見「儲備管理」一章。

# 金管局作為主動的負責任投資者，監察外聘投資經理的ESG作業手法

# 金管局的期望

金管局非常重視將ESG因素融入投資決定及主動行使資產擁有權等概念。為此，金管局在甄選聘任及監察外聘投資經理時，皆會考慮ESG因素。由於金管局認為就所持有的上市公司股票行使股東權利，是維護投資的長期價值的基本方針，因此會要求獲聘任的投資經理嚴肅對待主動行使資產擁有權一事。

# 金管局的監察

外聘投資經理須就其替金管局管理的上市股票組合的ESG表現接受評估。金管局透過溝通計劃，有系統地檢視外聘投資經理在不同範疇的ESG作業手法，例如其ESG評估架構、與獲投資公司的溝通，以及代理投票方面的工作。金管局在2020年選出若干外聘投資經理率先進行溝通計劃，當中不僅評估其ESG表現，亦檢視其有否代表金管局妥善行使資產擁有權。

# 溝通成果

金管局透過計劃識別出作業手法有問題的外聘投資經理，並採取跟進行動。下文列舉其中兩個例子。

# 個案1

金管局留意到股票投資經理A的ESG架構有改善空間，尤其應設立更有系統的方法去評估獲投資公司。金管局就此與A跟進，其後A進行全面的公司政策檢討，以實施一個更穩健的ESG架構。A更特別委任外聘顧問就ESG程序提供意見，反映加快落實改革的決心，並新設由高級管理層組成的ESG委員會，顯示對ESG的承擔及高級管理層對有關措施的支持。

# 個案2

金管局在檢視股票投資經理B的投票方法後，發現B的投票政策在多個範疇上都有不足之處，並要求其ESG主管作出審視。尤其B在過往的投票全數贊成管理層的建議，偏離其本身的代理投票指引。B其後承諾會加強公司的投票政策以符合期望，其中包括會提高ESG團隊成員的參與度，以及在遇上涉及重大管治問題時有可能對管理層投下反對票。

在私募市場投資方面，金管局藉着其專責合夥人致力與相關投資組合公司在ESG事宜上合作，從而實現負責任投資。金管局留意到專責合夥人都貫徹對ESG的承擔，因他們認為此舉可有利創造投資組合公司的長期價值和確保回報的可持續性。下文列舉的兩個例子顯示可透過(i)設計改動及利用創新運作技術；以及(ii)在建造及營運綠色及可持續倉庫時融入減碳因素，以管理氣候變化風險。兩個例子都對環境產生顯著的正面影響，減少碳排放，避免有害物質，並同時透過降低成本及節省能源，提升運作效率。

(i) 金管局有投資一間採用環保方案的害蟲防治公司。雖然傳統殺蟲劑及化學製品能有效殺滅害蟲，但若未能迅速清除或妥善棄置蟲屍，將會危害公共衛生。此外，化學成分的滲漏及棄置亦會造成環境問題。該公司採用的不含生物殺滅劑方案，透過設置捕蟲器以減少使用有害化學品。該公司亦利用與互聯網相連的動態感應器，遙距偵察是否已捕獲害蟲。藉着此項新技術，該公司能作出完善的路線規劃以收集捕獲的害蟲，減低出行里程，從而減少碳排放。該公司採用的方案令公司整體碳排的淨效應達到每美元淨銷售額0.36千克二氧化碳當量的低水平，接近法律服務及軟件出版等低碳行業的平均水平，實在令人鼓舞。

(ii) 金管局有投資綠色及可持續倉庫。雖然建造業是碳排放的一大源頭，但有關的倉庫發展商在其整體倉庫建造與營運中，採用淨零碳排放程序，並制定衡量淨零碳排放基準的標準及指標，而建築計劃亦顧及所用材料與部件的可持續性。因此，所建造的倉庫減碳效率高，並具備可持續特點，包括太陽能加熱系統、電動車充電設施、自然採光及雨水收集等。

根據獨立顧問的評估，按淨額計，有關倉庫建造的碳足跡較一般物流大廈的碳排放量低25.8%。為進一步抵銷建築工程所造成的碳排放，建造過程中更種植了32,799棵樹（以淨額計）。建成後倉庫的日常運作的碳排放量較一般倉庫少26.9%。

# Corporate Social Responsibility

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to fulfilling its corporate social responsibility goals by becoming a responsible and sustainable institution. The HKMA undertakes this commitment across various areas, including promoting sustainable development and environmentally conscious markets, caring for society at large, protecting the environment, and creating a friendly working environment.

To address the COVID-19 pandemic, the HKMA introduced multiple measures to support individuals and enterprises in need, thereby assisting Hong Kong's economy in overcoming difficult times.

# Market Environment

# Green and Sustainable Finance

Climate change is one of the major risks affecting human well-being and the global economy's sustainability. As a crucial part of society, the financial system is inevitably impacted; banks, as part of the financial system, should proactively manage climate risks. In this regard, the HKMA is dedicated to exploring approaches to tackle this challenge and is implementing several measures announced in May 2019 to promote the development of green finance in Hong Kong. These measures include the phased promotion of green and sustainable banking development:

# Phase One

Establishing a common framework with industry players to evaluate banks' current “green benchmarks” and collaborating with international organizations to provide technical support to local banks;

# Phase Two

Consulting industry and other stakeholders on regulatory expectations and requirements for green and sustainable banking; and

# Phase Three

Focusing on implementing, reviewing, and assessing the progress of banks in this area.

At the international level, the HKMA participates in multiple organizations, including the Central Banks and Supervisors Green Finance Network, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s Climate-related Financial Risks Task Force, the Bank Regulatory Working Group under the Central Bank and Monetary Authorities’ East Asia and Pacific Central Bank Governors’ Meeting, the Sustainable Finance Concern Group, and the International Platform on Sustainable Finance. Through engagement with these international organizations, the HKMA has opportunities to contribute to the work of central banks and regulators in addressing climate change, and can draw on experiences and perspectives from other regions when developing local frameworks.

The HKMA also participates in several working groups under the Central Banks and Supervisors Green Finance Network, including the Microprudential Supervision Working Group, the Macroeconomic and Financial Stability Working Group, and the Green Finance Promotion Working Group. Additionally, the HKMA has joined two newly established groups: the Research Working Group and the Data Gaps Filling Working Group. The Research Group is responsible for related research activities, while the Data Gaps Filling Group aims to develop a comprehensive list of data points currently lacking but necessary for regulators and financial institutions to assess climate-related risks and opportunities. Further details about the HKMA’s work in promoting green and sustainable banking this year can be found in the chapter on “Banking System Stability.”

In November, the HKMA jointly launched the Green Business Banking Alliance with the International Finance Corporation to assist banks in emerging markets in formulating responses to climate change. As a founding member and the first regional executive director of the Alliance, the HKMA is i) promoting the development of green commercial banking globally; ii) providing a platform for commercial banks to learn from each other, acquire knowledge, tools, and business information, thereby developing their own green finance roadmaps and transforming into credible green banks; iii) facilitating communication and discussing cutting-edge topics to advance the global green agenda; and iv) helping members collaborate and seize the green and climate-related investment opportunities estimated by the World Bank to reach up to USD 23 trillion over the next ten years in emerging markets.

Locally, the HKMA collaborates with other financial regulators to coordinate measures for the financial industry to tackle climate and environmental risks. In addition to supporting the government in implementing the Green Bond Program, the HKMA co-established the Cross-Agency Supervisory Group for Green and Sustainable Finance with the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC), which oversees cross-sector regulation and market development. Further details on the HKMA’s efforts this year to develop Hong Kong as a green and sustainable finance hub are available in the chapter on “Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Centre.”

# Cross-Agency Supervisory Group for Green and Sustainable Finance

The Group aims to coordinate the financial industry’s measures in response to climate and environmental risks, accelerate the development of green and sustainable finance in Hong Kong, and support the government’s climate strategies. Established jointly by the HKMA and the SFC in May, the Group’s other members include the Environment Bureau, the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, the Insurance Authority, and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority.

Since its inception, the Group has established two technical working teams responsible for researching and handling cross-departmental regulatory issues, as well as coordinating cross-agency market development initiatives.

In December, the Group issued a Green and Sustainable Finance Strategy, proposing six key areas to strengthen Hong Kong’s financial ecosystem and collaboratively build a greener and more sustainable future. The Group also announced five short-term action plans to address the most pressing issues in the development process.

The HKMA convened the inaugural meeting of the Group, with Chief Executive Mr. Eddie Yue (third from right) serving as co-chair.

The Group released Hong Kong’s Green and Sustainable Finance Strategy and five major action plans.

# Responsible Investment

The HKMA supports responsible investment, meaning the integration of Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors into investment activities. As a large asset owner, the HKMA’s increasing focus on responsible investment will influence how its fund managers conduct investment processes.

# HKMA’s Beliefs

The HKMA believes that by appropriately emphasizing responsible investment and considering the long-term sustainability of investment performance, it can more effectively achieve the investment goals of the Exchange Fund and reduce ESG-related risks involved in investment activities.

# HKMA’s Principles

According to the guiding principles adopted by the HKMA, when ESG investments have comparable risk-adjusted long-term returns to other investment options, priority is generally given to ESG investments. As a responsible long-term investor, the HKMA adopts the following principles in its investment management:

# Integration

The HKMA believes that ESG factors significantly impact the long-term value of investments, and therefore integrates ESG considerations into its investment analysis processes to identify risks and opportunities. These factors are incorporated into the investment management processes in both public markets and private equity markets.

# Active Exercise of Ownership Rights

The HKMA appropriately exercises shareholder rights for its holdings in listed companies to safeguard long-term investment value. The HKMA believes that responsible corporate behavior, considering ESG factors, will help create long-term shareholder benefits. The HKMA expects external investment managers to actively exercise ownership rights, including voting and engaging with investee companies, to assist it in fulfilling its ownership responsibilities.

# Collaboration

The HKMA strives to cooperate with like-minded investors and regulators to promote sound long-term investment management practices. It also participates in public events and delivers speeches to share improved ESG practices and encourage the investment community to adopt responsible investment principles.

Further details of the HKMA’s work on responsible investment this year can be found in the chapter on “Reserves Management.”

# HKMA as an Active Responsible Investor Monitoring External Managers’ ESG Practices

# HKMA’s Expectations

The HKMA attaches great importance to integrating ESG considerations into investment decisions and actively exercising ownership rights. Accordingly, it considers ESG factors when selecting and supervising external investment managers. Since exercising shareholder rights in listed companies is fundamental to maintaining long-term investment value, the HKMA requires appointed managers to take this responsibility seriously.

# HKMA’s Oversight

External investment managers are evaluated on their ESG performance in managing HKMA’s listed equity portfolios. Through systematic communication programs, the HKMA reviews their ESG practices in various areas, including ESG evaluation frameworks, engagement with investee companies, and proxy voting. In 2020, the HKMA selected several external managers to initiate communication programs, assessing not only their ESG performance but also whether they appropriately exercise ownership rights on behalf of the HKMA.

# Communication Outcomes

The HKMA identifies external managers with problematic practices through these programs and takes follow-up actions. Here are two examples:

# Case 1

The HKMA observed that Asset Management Company A’s ESG framework had room for improvement, especially in establishing more systematic methods for evaluating investee companies. The HKMA followed up with A, which subsequently conducted a comprehensive policy review to establish a more robust ESG framework. A also appointed external consultants for ESG processes, reflecting a determination to accelerate reforms, and established an ESG Committee composed of senior management, demonstrating commitment and support for ESG initiatives.

# Case 2

After reviewing Asset Management Company B’s voting procedures, the HKMA found deficiencies in B’s voting policies across multiple areas and requested an ESG review by B’s ESG head. Notably, B had historically voted in favor of management’s proposals in all cases, diverging from its own proxy voting guidelines. B subsequently committed to strengthen its voting policies to meet expectations, including increasing the participation of its ESG team members and considering opposition votes against management in cases involving significant governance issues.

In private markets, the HKMA leverages its dedicated partners to collaborate with portfolio companies on ESG matters, thereby advancing responsible investment. The HKMA has observed that these dedicated partners consistently uphold their commitments to ESG, believing that such efforts can generate long-term value for portfolio companies and ensure sustainable returns. The following two examples illustrate how innovations in approach and operational practices, including incorporating carbon reduction factors in building and operating green and sustainable warehouses, can significantly benefit the environment by reducing carbon emissions, preventing harmful substances, and simultaneously lowering costs and energy consumption:

(i) The HKMA invested in a pest control company that adopts environmentally friendly solutions. While conventional pest control agents and chemicals effectively kill pests, improper disposal or rapid removal of pest carcasses could jeopardize public health. The company uses a biocide-free approach, employing traps to reduce chemicals usage. It also utilizes internet-connected dynamic sensors to remotely detect pest captures. These innovations enable the company to plan routes efficiently for pest collection, reduce travel mileage, and consequently lower carbon emissions. The scheme results in a net carbon emission of only 0.36 kg of CO2 equivalent per dollar of net sales, comparable to low-carbon industries such as legal services and software publishing.

(ii) The HKMA invested in green and sustainable warehouses. Although the construction industry is a major source of carbon emissions, the warehouse developers implement net-zero CO2 emissions procedures and set standards and indicators for measuring these standards. Building plans also consider the sustainability of materials and components used. As a result, the warehouses have high carbon reduction efficiency and possess features such as solar thermal heating systems, electric vehicle charging facilities, natural lighting, and rainwater harvesting.

According to an independent assessment, the carbon footprint of these warehouses is approximately 25.8% lower than that of typical logistics warehouses. To further offset the carbon emissions from construction, 32,799 trees were planted during the process (net of the emissions). After completion, the daily operational carbon emissions of these warehouses are 26.9% lower than traditional warehouses.

# 意見

茲證明我已審計列載於第187至289頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2020年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括主要會計政策概要。

# 意見的基礎

我已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示及審計署的審計準則進行審計。我根據該等準則而須承擔的責任，詳載於本報告「審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任」部分。根據該等準則，我獨立於集團，並已按該等準則履行其他道德責任。我相信，我所獲得的審計憑證是充足和適當地為我的審計意見提供基礎。

# 關鍵審計事項

關鍵審計事項是根據我的專業判斷，對截至2020年12月31日止年度財務報表的審計最為重要的事項。我對整體財務報表進行審計及形成意見時處理了這些事項，而我不會對這些事項提供單獨的意見。

# 其他資料

金融管理專員須對其他資料負責。其他資料包括金融管理局2020年年報內的所有資料，但不包括財務報表及我的審計師報告。

我對財務報表的意見並不涵蓋其他資料，我亦不對其他資料發表任何形式的鑒證結論。

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而中肯的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制， 使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力，以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：
- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否中肯反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

我亦會向外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會提交聲明，說明我已符合有關獨立性的相關道德要求，並與他們溝通所有被合理認為可能會影響我獨立性的關係和其他事項，以及在適用的情況下，相關的防範措施。

從與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通的事項中，我會決定哪些事項對本期財務報表的審計最為重要，因而構成關鍵審計事項。我會在審計師報告中描述這些事項，除非法律法規不允許對某件事項作出公開披露，或在極端罕見的情況下，因為有合理預期在我報告中溝通某事項而造成的負面後果將會超過其產生的公眾利益而我決定不應在報告中溝通該事項。

附屬公司指集團所控制的實體。如集團因其參與該實體的營運而承擔有關浮動回報的風險或享有有關權利，且有能力對該實體行使權力而影響該等回報時，即屬擁有該實體的控制權。在評估集團是否擁有權力時，只考慮由集團及其他方所持有的實質權利。

# Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether caused by fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the Department of Audit’s standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these financial statements.

In performing an audit in accordance with the Department of Audit’s standards, I exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. I also:

- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and gather sufficient appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for error, as fraud may involve collusion, falsification, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or override of internal controls.
- Obtain an understanding of internal controls relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures, but not to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal controls.
- Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by management are appropriate and whether the accounting estimates and related disclosures are reasonable.
- Conclude on whether management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting is appropriate, and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether there are material uncertainties related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude there is a material uncertainty, I am required to draw attention in my auditor’s report to the related disclosures in the financial statements. If disclosures are inadequate, I am required to modify my opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of my auditor’s report; however, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease continuing as a going concern.
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements represent the underlying transactions and events fairly.
- Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or activities within the Group to express an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the audit, and I bear all the audit’s substantive and overall audit responsibility.

I communicate with the Audit Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control identified during the audit.

I also communicate with the Audit Committee regarding my independence and any relationships or other matters that may reasonably be thought to bear on my independence, in accordance with relevant ethical requirements, and to provide any safeguards that are applicable.

From the matters communicated with the Audit Committee, I determine which are the most significant for the audit of the current-year financial statements and therefore constitute key audit matters. I describe these matters in my auditor’s report unless law or regulation precludes public disclosure, or in extremely rare cases, I decide that the adverse consequences of disclosing a particular matter would outweigh the public interest benefits of such disclosure.
